column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=The Essen Barges
#Text=I lay for four days like a log in that garret bed .
#Text=The storm died down , the thaw set in , and the snow melted .
#Text=The children played about the doors and told stories at night round the fire .
#Text=Stumm 's myrmidons no doubt beset every road and troubled the lives of innocent wayfarers .
#Text=But no one came near the cottage , and the fever worked itself out while I lay in peace .
#Text=It was a bad bout , but on the fifth day it left me , and I lay , as weak as a kitten , staring at the rafters and the little skylight .
#Text=It was a leaky , draughty old place , but the woman of the cottage had heaped deerskins and blankets on my bed and kept me warm .
#Text=She came in now and then , and once she brought me a brew of some bitter herbs which greatly refreshed me .
#Text=A little thin porridge was all the food I could eat , and some chocolate made from the slabs in my rucksack .
#Text=I lay and dozed through the day , hearing the faint chatter of children below , and getting stronger hourly .
#Text=Malaria passes as quickly as it comes and leaves a man little the worse , though this was one of the sharpest turns I ever had .
#Text=As I lay I thought , and my thoughts followed curious lines .
#Text=One queer thing was that Stumm and his doings seemed to have been shot back into a lumber-room of my brain and the door locked .
#Text=He did n't seem to be a creature of the living present , but a distant memory on which I could look calmly .
#Text=I thought a good deal about my battalion and the comedy of my present position . You see I was getting better , for I called it comedy now , not tragedy .
#Text=But chiefly I thought of my mission .
#Text=All that wild day in the snow it had seemed the merest farce .
#Text=The three words Harry Bullivant had scribbled had danced through my head in a crazy fandango .
#Text=They were present to me now , but coolly and sanely in all their meagreness .
#Text=I remember that I took each one separately and chewed on it for hours .
#Text=Kasredin -- there was nothing to be got out of that .
#Text=Cancer -- there were too many meanings , all blind . V. I. -- that was the worst gibberish of all .
#Text=Before this I had always taken the I as the letter of the alphabet .
#Text=I had thought the v. must stand for von , and I had considered the German names beginning with I -- Ingolstadt , Ingeburg , Ingenohl , and all the rest of them .
#Text=I had made a list of about seventy at the British Museum before I left London .
#Text=Now I suddenly found myself taking the I as the numeral One .
#Text=Idly , not thinking what I was doing , I put it into German .
#Text=Then I nearly fell out of the bed .
#Text=Von Einem -- the name I had heard at Gaudian 's house , the name Stumm had spoken behind his hand , the name to which Hilda was probably the prefix .
#Text=It was a tremendous discovery -- the first real bit of light I had found .
#Text=Harry Bullivant knew that some man or woman called von Einem was at the heart of the mystery .
#Text=Stumm had spoken of the same personage with respect and in connection with the work I proposed to do in raising the Moslem Africans .
#Text=If I found von Einem I would be getting very warm .
#Text=What was the word that Stumm had whispered to Gaudian and scared that worthy ?
#Text=It had sounded like uhnmantl .
#Text=If I could only get that clear , I would solve the riddle .
#Text=I think that discovery completed my cure .
#Text=At any rate on the evening of the fifth day -- it was Wednesday , the 29th of December -- I was well enough to get up .
#Text=When the dark had fallen and it was too late to fear a visitor , I came downstairs and , wrapped in my green cape , took a seat by the fire .
#Text=As we sat there in the firelight , with the three white-headed children staring at me with saucer eyes , and smiling when I looked their way , the woman talked .
#Text=Her man had gone to the wars on the Eastern front , and the last she had heard from him he was in a Polish bog and longing for his dry native woodlands .
#Text=The struggle meant little to her .
#Text=It was an act of God , a thunderbolt out of the sky , which had taken a husband from her , and might soon make her a widow and her children fatherless .

#Text=She knew nothing of its causes and purposes , and thought of the Russians as a gigantic nation of savages , heathens who had never been converted , and who would eat up German homes if the good Lord and the brave German soldiers did not stop them .
#Text=I tried hard to find out if she had any notion of affairs in the West , but she had n't , beyond the fact that there was trouble with the French .
#Text=I doubt if she knew of England 's share in it .
#Text=She was a decent soul , with no bitterness against anybody , not even the Russians if they would spare her man .
#Text=That night I realized the crazy folly of war .
#Text=When I saw the splintered shell of Ypres and heard hideous tales of German doings , I used to want to see the whole land of the Boche given up to fire and sword .
#Text=I thought we could never end the war properly without giving the Huns some of their own medicine .
#Text=But that woodcutter 's cottage cured me of such nightmares .
#Text=I was for punishing the guilty but letting the innocent go free .
#Text=It was our business to thank God and keep our hands clean from the ugly blunders to which Germany 's madness had driven her .

#Text=What good would it do Christian folk to burn poor little huts like this and leave children 's bodies by the wayside ? To be able to laugh and to be merciful are the only things that make man better than the beasts .
